subject: Again... with testing interfaces...
msgSnippet: Imagine an interface I.  Class X implements I.  Class Y extends X. With my current use of Junit, I ve taken the Inner Test Class for implemented interfaces
messageBody:
Imagine an interface I. Class X implements I. Class Y extends X.

With my current use of Junit, I've taken the "Inner Test Class for
implemented interfaces" route. That is, and I'll prefix test classes w/
a T...

TX extends TestCase
TX has an inner test class, TI

TX's suite includes TX and TX.TI

I'm running into a situation where I'd like to have the factory method
in TI to create an instance of X. No problem, create a new instance and
return.

However, when I get to Y, obviously it's still going to be creating an
instance of X. What I'd really like to do is have the factory method in
TI call the factory method in TX to create an instance of X. Thus, in
TY, I would simply override this method and return an instance of Y
instead. This would allow me to execute TY which would run TY's tests,
TX's tests, and TI's tests all against an instance of Y.

Questions:

1. How do I build the suite in TY?
2. How can I properly link the factory methods so that I can properly
override them?
- e.g. previously, I tried - TI.createI() would call
TX.createX(). I can't do this
as when I get to TY, TI is still referencing TX through a static
reference.

My problem with the inner class approach is that I would have to
reimplement a TI for each subclass of X to ensure that that subclass
didn't break the contract of I by overriding methods, etc.

Due diligence on the human side would allow me to avoid any complex
automation of test inheritance, but humans forget and this will
hopefully allievate the problems when humans forget.

Maybe I'm approaching this all wrong. A fresh set of eyes would be
helpful.

I've read mentions of using a parameterized test case, but I'm not
finding examples that fit the context of my problem.

Any help would be great!

Thanks,

Tom
